Introduction

Learning JavaScript data types and loops.

var lesson = 'Data Types and Loops'; var teacher = "Kenny";

JavaScript Basics

Skip ahead if you know some JavaScript!

JavaScript

What is it?

  • It's not Java.
  • It's an ECMAScript Specification.
  • It was invented at Netscape and is implemented in all modern browsers.
  • It busted out of the browser ( node.js ).

What can it do?

Make webpages live. How?

  • Modify the page. ( Write, add, remove, style, etc. )
  • Execute code on events ( Mouse, keyboard, browser, etc. )
  • AJAX ( Send requests to server and handle responses. )
  • Create, read, update, delete cookies. ( CRUD )
  • Communicate with user, and prompt for input.

Everything else.

How do I do it?

The easiest way to embed it in a page is with a script tag.

<script>code goes here...</script>

Save this in a file and open with a browser.

<!doctype html>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>Enter your name here</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <script>
      alert('Hello World');
    </script>
  </body>
</html>

Or use the browser JavaScript Console to try out code.

Basics

Simple Debugging

alert('Hi'); console.log('Hi') document.write('Hi')

Statements

  • Code consists of many statements.
  • Separate statements with a semicolon, or pay the price!
  • Spaces and tabs are ignored.

A few statements...

var i = 12;
var j = 8;
alert(i + j);

Three statements in one line...

var i = 12; var j = 8; alert(i + j);

It works, but it's not as readable.

Variables

Creating a variable is easy.

var myVariable = "Some Value";

We use the var directive to create variables.

var i = 0;
var j = 1;
var k = "text goes here";

Practice good naming conventions.

  • Names are case sensitive! ( You should use camelCase. )
  • Can contain letters, digits, underscores and dollar signs.
  • Must begin with a letter, a dollar sign or an underscore.
  • Name should try to describe the variable's use.

    • You can declare multiple variables in one line with commas...

    var i = 0, j = 1, k = "text goes here";

    ...or in multiple lines.

    var i = 0,
        j = 1,
        k = "text goes here";

    A little cleaner.

    You can also declare empty variables and assign them values later

    var i; // I'm empty
    var a, b, c; // We are too
    var d = "I have a value :)"; // Not empty
    i = d; // Not empty anymore
    alert(i);

    Once you declare a variable you can use it.

    var i;
    console.log(i); // prints undefined
    i = 1;
    console.log(i); // prints 1

    camelCase

    var isMobile;
    var isCamelCase = true;

    not camelCase.

    var ismobile;
    var iscamelcase = false;

    Comments

    • Comments get ignored.
    • Use comments to explain code that is not obvious.
    • Use comments to describe objects or functions.
    • Use comments to mark a future task. ( TODO )

    Single line comments start with //

    // here's a comment from the code on this page
    // this might help me later
    // or someone else looking at my code

    // this will disable scrollbars
    $document[0].body.style.overflow = 'hidden';

    Multiline comments start with /* and end with */,

    with some * in between.

    /*
    * This is how they do it...
    * ...and like this.
    * ...and like this.
    * ...and like this.
    *
    */

    /* We still can do a one liner though. */

    Blocks

    // blocks are multiple statements wrapped in curly brackets
    // there's no use for standalone blocks
    // but we use them for more complex things later
    {
      var one = 1;
      var two = 2;
      alert(one * 2);
    }

    Operators

    Arithmetic Operators
    +, -, *, /, %

    // these operators are used for simple math
    console.log(4 + 2) // prints 6
    console.log(4 - 2) // prints 2
    console.log(4 * 2) // prints 8
    console.log(4 / 2) // prints 2
    console.log(4 % 2) // prints 0

    String Concatenation

    Putting pieces of text together with +.

    var myString = "My" + " " + "String";
    alert(myString); // My String

    Increment/Decrement
    ++, --

    var i = 0;
    i++;
    console.log(i); // prints 1
    i--;
    console.log(i); // prints 0

    Logical Operators
    &&, ||, !

    var isTasty = true, isCheap = true, isFree = false;
    alert(isTasty && isCheap) // AND;
    alert(isCheap || isFree) // OR;
    alert(!isFree) // NOT

    Assignment Operators
    =, +=, -=, *=, /=

    These are the basic assignment operators used to assign values to variables.

    var i = 1;
    console.log(i += 1); // prints 2
    console.log(i -= 1); // prints 1
    console.log(i *= 3); // prints 3
    console.log(i /= 3); // prints 1

    Comparison Operators
    ==, ===, !=, !==

    Use these to compare two statements.

    var i = false,
    j = "";
    console.log(i == j); // equality
    console.log(i === j); // strict equality
    console.log(i != j); // inequality
    console.log(i !== j); // strict inequality

    More Comparison Operators
    >, >=, <, <=

    var i = 5, j = 5;
    console.log(i < j); // less than
    console.log(i <= j); // less than or equal to
    console.log(i > j); // greater than
    console.log(i >= j); // greater than or equal to

    Conditionals

    if

    var isCoding = true;
    if(isCoding) alert("I'm coding!");

    The same thing with a block.

    var isCoding = true;
    if(isCoding) {
      // could add more code here
      alert("I'm coding!");
    }

    if..else

    var isCoding = true;
    if(isCoding)
      alert("I'm coding!");
    else
      alert("I'm not coding!");

    The same thing with less lines.

    var isCoding = true;
    if(isCoding) alert("I'm coding!")
    else alert("I'm not coding!");

    The same thing with blocks.

    var isCoding = true;
    if(isCoding) {
      alert("I'm coding!");
    } else {
      alert("I'm not coding!");
    }

    Data Types

    Why have data types?

    Data types solve this problem.

    var confusing = 3 + "three";

    Types identify data,
    determine it's possible values,
    and the operations that can be done on that data.

    Dynamic Types

    You can change the type of a variable.

    var x = 0; // I'm a Number!
    x = "Some text."; // I'm a String!
    x = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]; // I'm an Array!

    How do I check type?

    The typeof operator.

    typeof "Kenny" // Returns "string"
    typeof 73 // Returns "number"
    typeof true // Returns "boolean"
    typeof {make:'kia', model:'optima'} // Returns "object" typeof undefined; // Returns "undefined"

    Primitive Types

    • Boolean
    • Null
    • Undefined
    • Number
    • String
    • Symbol ( new in EMCAScript 6)

    Booleans

    true || false

    To be or not to be.

    A Boolean can only be true or false.

    var myBoolean = true;
    if(myBoolean) alert('It is true!');

    // now assign false
    myBoolean = false;
    if(!myBoolean) alert('It is false!');

    Null

    • The Null type can only have one value. ( null )
    • Null is sometimes used when an object is expected but non are relevant.

    Undefined

    When a variable has not been assigned a value, it has the value of undefined.

    var i;
    alert(i); // undefined
    i = true;
    alert(i); // true

    Numbers

    • Integers (1, 2, 3, -1, -2, -3)
    • Floating point numbers (1.2, 1.34, -1.0345)
    • and more ( hex, scientific notation ).

    Valid numbers.

    var a = 100, b = -100;
    var c = -10000.083, d = 3.3;
    var e = 0x000000; // 0
    var y = 123e5; // 12300000
    var z = 123e-5; // 0.00123

    Invalid numbers.

    var a = 00;
    var b = 0xx098;
    var c = "0"1;

    Important Number Methods

    toFixed(n)
    Formats a number with n number decimals.

    toString()
    Converts the number to a string.

    Format decimals. No Problem.

    Use Number.toFixed(n).

    var num = 100.123;
    num.toFixed(2) //100.12
    num.toFixed(1) //100.1

    Number to String Conversion.

    Use Number.toString().

    var num = 100.123;
    num.toString() //"100.123"

    String to Number Conversion.

    Use the global methods parseInt and parseFloat.

    var num = parseInt("10"); // returns 10 var num = parseInt("10.33"); // returns 10 var num = parseFloat("10.33"); // returns 10.33

    Strings

    var myString = "Hello World";
    • A series of characters.
    • Can be empty, one or many characters.
    • You can use single or double quotes.

    Valid string examples.

    var one = "one";
    var two = '2';
    var three = 'Th' + "r" + 'ee';
    var four = ""; // I'm empty but I'm legal

    Invalid strings.

    var foo = bar;
    var bar = "foo;
    var bad = "s"s";

    String.length

    The length property of a String.

    var myString = "Hello";
    alert(myString.length); // 5

    String Methods

    • String.charAt() ( Get the character at a point in the String. )
    • String.concat() ( Join one or more Strings. )
    • String.substr() ( Extract part of a String. )
    • String.replace() ( Replace part of a String. )
    • And many, many more...
    var myString = "Hello World";
    var hello = myString.substr(0, 5);
    var world = myString.substr(6, 5);
    alert(hello + " " + world);

    Composite Types

    • Object
    • Array

    Objects

    Objects have properties and methods.

    Object Properties

    • Properties are like variables.
    • They are name:value pairs.
    • It's easy to write Objects with curly brackets.
      • var myObject = { name:"Kenny", age:38 };

    Object Methods

    It's just a function stored in a Object property.

    var myObject = {
    sayHello:function(){ alert("Hello"); }
    };

    myObject.sayHello(); // alerts "Hello"

    Property and method access.

    var object = { name:"kenny", age:38 };
    alert(object.name); // dot notation
    alert(object['age']); // bracket notation

    Arrays

    • Arrays are a type of Object.
    • They let you store multiple values in one variable.
    • Instead of name:value pairs, they are int:value pairs.
    • Use square brackets to create them.

    Creating Arrays

    var myNumberArray = [1, 2, 3];
    var myNameArray = ["Kenny", "Cosca"];
    var myMixedArray = [7, "text", true];

    Array Indexes

    Arrays are indexed starting with 0.

    var myArray = ["zero", "one", "two"];
    console.log(myArray[0]); // "zero"
    console.log(myArray[2]); // "two"
    console.log(myArray[3]); // Oh no! Error!

    Loops

    for

    For loops are great for Arrays!

    var fruits = ['apple', 'orange', 'pear'];

    // we're looping through our fruits Array
    for(var i = 0; i < fruits.length; i++){
      console.log(fruits[i]);
    }

    while

    var i = 0;
    while(i < 10) {
      console.log(i);
      i++;
    }

    do..while

    var i = 0;
    do{
      // this happens once no matter what!
      console.log(i);
      i++;
    } while (i < 10)

    for..in

    var teacher = { name: 'Kenny', mood: 'Happy' }

    // it's perfect for looping through object properties
    for(var i in teacher){
      console.log(i);
      console.log(teacher[i]);
    }

    Switch

    switch(event.which)
    {
      case 37: // left
        scope.down();
        break;
      case 38: // up
        scope.up();
        break;
      case 39: // right
        scope.up();
        break;
      case 40: // down
        scope.down();
        break;
    }
